results.notes:
Growing in soil, small clusters & scattered under some partial shade, also found on a grass lawn a few meters away.
Weather humid 80% scattered rain & 30c days lately.
Mostly white, cap circular & smooth with bronze tint / fade from center.
Starts egg shaped to convex, then flat & slightly depressed.
Margins entire to crisped & decurved and they also peel back / upward as they mature.
Lamellae close with intermediate lengths, white, free, free.
Stipe central with bulbous base, surface texture longitudinally striate.
Ring present, flaring / sheathing upwards

results.notes:
These were soft/pliable and not degrading as far as I could tell. This limb of the tree (honey locust I think) has been dead for a while, at least 2 years, but I really don’t think this many fungi were on it until this winter some time. I walk by there frequently and I would have expected to notice.

These had a really obvious “classic mushroom” smell. Sweet/earthy.

They were up too high so one had to get knocked down with a stick.

I have the 1 that was knocked down, it was left to dry out naturally/by air indoors.

results.notes:
Spores ellipsoid, simple, hyaline, 3 measured: 8.7 × 3.5 um; 7.7 × 3.5 um; 8.8 × 3.6 hard to determine spore maturity

Macro: apothecia matte black, some finely white-pruinose making the the ap look a bit lighter black, margin gen. raised above disc surface, black/concolorous with ap surface. Aps with sinuous margins, averaging 0.5 mm diam. Thallus visible between sand grains, grayish-white, hard to see, partly chasmolithic to epilithic. Micro: epihymenium black, hymenium hyaline, area below hymenium brown.

Thallus K+Y in section (not K+R norstictic acid). I test for medulla negative. Applied lugol’s iodine to thallus sections in water, cleared with more water (no reaction), then applied KOH (still no blue), and then another round of Lugol’s followed by water. Never any blue reaction evident.

Keyed to couplet 29 in Nash 2007 Lecidea key, which is between L. hassei and laboriosa and requires chemistry that I don’t know where to begin with (schizopeltic acid (hassei) vs. 4-O-demethylplanaic acid). Hassei is described as very rare and endolithic, while laboriosa can be “scarcely epilithic” which this specimen is.

results.notes:
Spores brownish, 1-septate, 3 measured: 11.6 × 7.2, 13.7 × 7.5, and 13.0 × 6.5 um. Spores seemed to show slight constriction at septation.

Macro: thallus brown, continuous areolate, areoles angular, many with gray margins. Cracks between areoles quite deep. Margins of thallus with fingerlike extensions, same color or a bit darker than rest of thallus. Originally thought this was hypothallus, but now not really sure since it’s a similar color. Collection contains multiple specimens, all under 1 cm diam (largest approaching 1cm). Apothecia black with raised black rim, ~0.5 mm diam on average, flat becoming convex, adnate. Apothecia surface grainy/rough looking. Micro: apothecia with black, lecideine margin, ~45 um thick. Area below hymenium dark brown, hymenium hyaline, around 60-70 um tall, epihymenium thick and composed of dark brown round grains. Thallus with thin (~5um) epinecral layer, thin brown cortex (5-10 um) immediately underlain by algal cells.

Thallus K-, KC- in section. Apothecia K- and C-.

results.notes:
On disintigrating white shale overlaid by sand, HCL- in dry annual grassland habitat. Apothecia densely abundant, plane, bicolored with light orange thin rim and medium orange epruinose disk. Thalline margin absent or severely reduced. Proper margin thin. Algae continuous across base but not thick and uneven along the upper edge. Paraphyses simple, somewhat expanded at apice to about 3µm. Spore average size: 12.7×5.4µm with septum of 4.0µm (n=6).

Spore measurements a little narrow but otherwise this fits well with C. subpyraceella.
results.location_name: Casmalia, Santa Barbara Co., California, USA
Casmalia, Santa Barbara Co., California, USA

results.notes:
On north side trunk of a huge valley oak (Quercus lobata). Thallus immersed showing very thinly as grey to yellowish orange esorediate and continuous crust. Apothecia emergent, with a thick light yellow-orange margin quickly becoming reduced to leave the proper margin dominant. Proper margin concolorous to slightly lighter than disk, disk medium orange and epruinose, reduced thalline margin yellowish to grey on outer lower edge. In section the epihymenium is dark orange, hymenium hyaline, and the algal layer continuous and uneven to irregular clumps. Paraphyses simple and thin, scarcely expanding at apice to 2.5µm, often with an epithecial granule. Spores broadly ellipsoid, average size 13.4×7.2µ with isthmus wide at 4.9µ (n=3).

Still not comfortable with these but this seems to fit. Photos don’t show thallus well.
results.location_name: Paso Robles, California, USA

results.notes:
Spores: Simple, hyaline, ovoid, 8/ascus. 2 measured: 10.4 × 5.9, 9.7 × 6.7 um

Macro: Thallus a clean white, continuous-areolate, areoles sharply angular. Thallus surface chalky white almost looking like it’s caked in something. Apothecia immersed, flush with thallus surface, black. Some apothecia with a light dusting of fine white pruina. Largest apothecia on specimen ~0.7mm avg. diam.

Micro: apothecia with dark turquoise epihymenium. Exciple is not obvious. Hymenium hyaline, ~50 um tall.

Chemistry: Medulla I- in thallus, but I+ violet (or dark purple?) under hypothecium. Hymenium I+ blue. No C or K reactions evident.

Keying using the Nash 2007 Lecidea key did not go very well. However, many of this specimen’s characteristics seem to line up with Lecidea tessellata, aside from the fact that the apothecia are situated around the middle of the areoles.

results.notes:
Spores: Simple, hyaline, ellipsoid, measured 4: 15.7 × 7.5, 13.6 × 6.6, 11.7 × 5.3, 13.6 × 5.7 um. Unsure about maturity of measured spores.

Macro: Thallus shiny brown, continuous areolate to subsquamulose, areoles convex and with rounded edges, making each areole look independent (i.e. thallus doesn’t have “cracked” appearance. Some apothecia large, flat to convex, often with subdivisions and/or a middle “dimple” (more than one fused together?). Ap rim looks gray-black from above, darker black when along the sides. Larger aps approaching 2mm diameter, regularly ~1mm diam. Almost looks like sometimes apothecia have grown together and merged, unsure. Micro: thallus epinecral layer even across thallus surface, ~5um thick where measured. Cortex brown, ~20 um thick. Algal layer above medulla full of algae, spread consistently (no clumping or variegation). Medulla white, breaking apart easily, hard to section. Hymenium hyaline, hymenium + subhymeium measured ~115 um tall incl. epihymenium and down to pigmented hypothecium (unclear boundaries between hymenium, subhymenium). Epihym dark brown-green. Hypothecium light reddish brown, consistently so among apothecia sectioned, including one smaller, younger apothecium.

Chemistry: Exciple ephemerally C+ red, hymenium strongly I+ blue (as well as rest of apothecium I think), medulla in thallus section looks I-. C+ rose-red reaction in thallus coming from cortex I believe. Parts of thallus in section (in medulla I think) were giving a K+orange reaction, though I’m wondering if this was coming from something in the underlying substrate. Spot test on exposed medulla gave a K+ light yellowish reaction I think.

results.notes: This curious encounter occurred a while back and I should have paid better attention. It was on a log in seasonally dry forest. It was good-sized, maybe even a hand-print in extent. It had a rubbery jelly-like consistency and was not very fragile. Dry and not sticky to touch. Whitish opaque and darker translucent. It did not apparently change rapidly, that I noticed. Regrettably, this is the only view I have. I have never seen a jelly fungus that was so opaque, but I have no other ideas.

results.notes:
On Clusia rosea leaves. Spores about 10-12×5 with germ slit spore length or nearly so on the ventral side. Hyaline cellular appendage apparent in H20 in some spores. Stromata velutinate, perithecia scarce in collection, present as single hardly discernible swellings in the middle of the stromata, the rest infertile. Some structures appear rhizomorphic, apparently sterile and binding leaves together.

—

notes_fields.Habitat: Growing, with Stereum complicatum, on an oak branch (ca. 2” diameter) that fell from a Quercus nigra (Water Oak) tree.
notes_fields.Fruitbody: Yellow, multi-lobe gelatinous mass. Cross-section reveals a white center, composed of mycelium, covered in a layer of golden-yellow gelatinous tissue. Basidia are 4-septate without apparent sterigmata.
notes_fields.Remarks:
It has been suggested that this might be Tremella steidleri. A description…
‘Tremella steidleri is a European species that is parasitic on Stereum hirsutum and grows on rotten wood from broadleaf trees, especially oak. The basidia are described as subspherical, 2-4 spored, with long sterigmata.’
http://www.leifgoodwin.co.uk/Fungi/Tremella%20steidleri.html
My examination of the basidia indicated that they are 4-septate, but I couldn’t find any indication of the formation of sterigmata.
Sequencing will be necessary to identify this fungus.

results.notes:
Habitat: Mixed pine-hardwoods, shortleaf pine and oaks, ground
Cap: 5 cm, orange-red, yellow margin, planoconvex, smooth, dry, stained dark blue; context bright yellow, stained weakly blue
Pore surface: saffron yellow, slightly depressed at stalk, 3 pores/mm, tube depth 6 mm, stained dark blue
Stalk: 7 cm length, 16 mm apex, 22 mm base, yellow at apex, red reticulation at apex, yellow ground color, red punctae, curved at base, basal mycelium yellow, stained dark blue; flesh bright yellow, stained weakly, slow to stain in tip of base
Chemical reactions: on cap—KOH yellow, NH4OH negative or orange, FeSO4 brownish
Odor and taste: not distinctive
Spore print: olive brown

results.notes:
Location: Priest Point Park Olympia, WA, USA. 6 fruiting bodies beneath Western red cedar and Douglas fir. Harvested/dried 3 fruiting bodies for herbarium collection. Spore printed a single cap directly on a glass slide for microscopy. Spores: smooth, clear, ellipsoid. Macro features- cherry red cap(5-7cm wide). Stem: 6-8cm long, thick, yellow(dry) white at base cast/streaked pink vertically in mature specimens. Gills: peach cast. Multiple images of spore micro included in observation. Images of macro measurements also included. This is the third season I have encountered H. laetissima here at Priest point park.

2/15/2021: mailed dried specimens from this collection to curator at Burke herbarium UW.

results.notes:
Habitat: Roadside mossy bank near deciduous woods, ground
Cap: 3.3 cm, depth 1 cm in middle, depth 8 mm in middle of side, dull, pale mustard yellow, convex, dry, slightly rugose around margin; context light yellow, stained blue, under cuticle didn’t stain
Pore surface: greenish, slightly decurrent, slowly stains blue, 3 pores/mm, tube depth 2.5 mm
Stalk: 4.5 cm length, 7 mm apex, 8 mm base at ground, 9 mm base underground, cream yellow with some rust in middle, no reticulation, darker yellow overnight; flesh yellow at apex, lighter yellow below, cream at base, no staining
Chemical reactions: on cap—KOH orange flash then reddish brown, NH4OH ochre, stalk flesh—FeSO4 grayish
Odor and taste: odor like green corn
Spore print: olive brown
